ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: More cultural knowledge related to Swahili, a few grammatical concepts, and lots of vocabulary.
Learned the language of Kiswahili, as well as the cultural history that has surrounded the language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed that this course taught us more about the Kenyan and Tanzanian culture through the many readings that we did. I enjoyed how we discussed current issues through the reading/listening of new articles/reports. I think the individual presentations were a great way to practice speaking but also to get to talk about something you care about, not just what we were learning about that week. I did not like that so much of the class and tests were based around the memorization of massive amounts of vocabulary, as I think there could have been more application or culture-based learning methods.
The course was good. Professor Waweru was engaging and comfortable to talk to, and helped us to learn more about the language and the culture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Kiswahili has been a great language. Professors are engaging, the language isn't too difficult, but it's still very interesting to see the ways in which it is constructed, and the ways in which it is different from more traditional languages students learn in the West. It's also interesting to get to talk and learn about the history of Eastern Africa, which often isn't taught in American schools (or at least it wasn't in mine).
